strategic_context.current_situation: Employed at MoneyGram, cannot publicly announce agency
strategic_context.positioning_goal: Build credibility as AI-native business operator without selling services

timeline.now: Build credibility through content and projects
timeline.2026: Launch AI agency targeting US SMBs

headline.recommended: Senior Sales Manager @ MoneyGram | Building AI-powered systems for GTM, ops & product | 20+ automation projects
headline.rationale: Shows real job (safe), building things (credibility), understands business functions (not just AI as toy)

about_section.recommended:
I've spent 10 years in sales and GTM. Now I build AI systems that do what used to take teams weeks.

Not because AI is trendy—because I got tired of watching good strategies die in execution.

What I'm working on now:
• Automating the boring parts of sales ops
• Building internal tools that actually get used
• Figuring out where AI creates leverage vs. where it creates noise

I share what I'm learning here. Sometimes it works. Sometimes it doesn't. That's the point.
about_section.rationale: Frames as practitioner, not consultant. Employer-safe, recruiter-attractive, builds agency credibility without announcing it.

what_it_signals.to_recruiters: Sales leader who's evolved into product/ops thinking
what_it_signals.to_future_clients: Someone who clearly knows what they're doing

recommended_content: Best 'What I Built' post with engagement
Article or post showing cross-functional perspective
avoid: Anything that looks like a service offering
Content that's too sales-focused without evolution angle

one_liner_options.for_linkedin: Building AI systems that turn GTM strategies into execution
one_liner_options.for_conversations: I build the automation layer that makes sales and product actually work together
one_liner_options.for_future_agency: Helping boring businesses automate the work nobody wants to do

what_makes_this_different: Not 'AI consultant'—too agency-forward, risky with employer
Not 'Sales leader'—too backward-looking for where Diego is going
Not 'Product manager'—doesn't have the title yet
AI-native business operator = practitioner who builds, not advisor who talks

unique_value_propositions.proposition: Tri-force: Sales execution + Product thinking + Technical building
unique_value_propositions.proof: $30M+ B2B sales, 20+ AI projects built, SQL/Python/Power BI skills

unique_value_propositions.proposition: Builder who ships, not consultant who decks
unique_value_propositions.proof: Actual automations, tools, and systems shared publicly
unique_value_propositions.when_to_lead_with: All content—this is the core differentiator

unique_value_propositions.proof: Case studies from HVAC/trades (build these through 'helping friends')

to_build.how: Help friends/family in HVAC, trades, services—document learnings
to_build.framing: 'I've been helping a friend automate their HVAC business'

to_build.how: Share screenshots, workflows, results on LinkedIn
Document any product-sales alignment work at MoneyGram (carefully)
to_build.framing: 'A pattern I've noticed working across teams'

core_principles.meaning: The real work is connecting AI to existing workflows, not running pilots
core_principles.content_angle: Most AI fails because of integration, not the AI

core_principles.meaning: Automate the unsexy stuff first—scheduling, follow-ups, reporting
core_principles.content_angle: The biggest opportunities are in the most boring businesses

core_principles.meaning: Any tool is 20% of the value. The system is 80%.
core_principles.content_angle: Stop evaluating tools. Start designing systems.

core_principles.meaning: Start with the business problem, not the shiny solution
core_principles.content_angle: What problem are you actually solving?

core_principles.meaning: Learning in public builds trust faster than polished expertise
core_principles.content_angle: Here's what worked. Here's what didn't. Here's what I'd do differently.

beliefs_to_express: The best AI implementations are invisible to users
Customization is often a trap—simplicity usually wins
Speed of execution matters more than perfect strategy
Small businesses have bigger AI opportunities than enterprises
The future belongs to people who can build, not just advise

not_competing_with.why_different: Too slow, too expensive, too theoretical. Diego builds.
They lack business strategy and GTM understanding

actual_competition: Other fractional executives in digital transformation
Product strategy consultants who can also execute
winning_factors: Unique combination: sales + product + technical execution
Practitioner who builds, not just advises

target_market.rationale: High revenue, low tech adoption, underserved, pay for results

service_concept.core_offer: AI automation systems for boring businesses

how_to_build_toward_it.content_frame: 'Helping a friend automate their HVAC business—here's what I learned'

how_to_build_toward_it.action: Build case studies without calling them case studies
how_to_build_toward_it.content_frame: 'Before/after of a scheduling system I built'
'The biggest AI opportunities are in industries nobody's talking about'
When someone DMs 'do you do this for clients?'—that's the signal

what_not_to_do: Use language that sounds like moonlighting
Create a separate agency LinkedIn page (yet)

target_companies.type: US tech companies, mid-size to growth stage
target_companies.characteristics: Value cross-functional experience, building capability, AI-native thinking

signals_to_send.how: Use product language: user problems, adoption, workflow design, internal tools
Show actual builds, not just tool usage
'Built this to solve a gap between sales and product'
Every post should demonstrate AI fluency

career_pivot_positioning.recruiter_perception_goal: This person thinks like a PM, has sales credibility, AND can actually build things

immediate_actions.new_headline: Senior Sales Manager @ MoneyGram | Building AI-powered systems for GTM, ops & product | 20+ automation projects

immediate_actions.criteria: Does each fit the three pillars?

immediate_actions.action: Start one boring business case study
